This transmits revised IRM 25.3.6, Litigation and Judgments, Open Litigation Control, Monitoring, and Closing Actions.
IRM 25.3.6.2.1.1: Updated references and clariﬁed content.
IRM 25.3.6.2.2: Revised and clariﬁed section contents. Added two step tables IRM 25.3.6.3.2.2, Short CSED Suit Recommendation Actions, and IRM 25.3.6.3.2.2, Expired CSED on Litigation Case.
IRM 25.3.6.3: Added eApproval content and revises content for clarity.
IRM 25.3.6.3.1: Updated to add current time-keeping litigation codes. Added two tables listing the current time controls IRM 25.3.6.3.1, Preliminary Controls:, and IRM 25.3.6.3.1, Suit Controls.

Deleted section titled, Account Records Review, as content covered in IRM
, Periodic Open Case Reviews. Added new section titled, Using
pproval Post Prep-For Counsel, with new content for using certain
pproval reports to control litigation work.
IRM 25.3.6.4: Revised content to include use of Form 14187, Periodic Open Litigation Case Review,
IRM 25.3.6.5.2.2: Added new section titled, Partial Resolution of Judgment or Settlement. and a step table IRM 25.3.6.5.2.2, Adjustment Actions.
IRM 25.3.6.5.3.2, Added new section titled, Specialized Non-FORT Adjustments.

Added the following caution at various points in the IRM - Contact the Centralized Insolvency Operation (CIO), if an account is in bankruptcy and risks discharge during litigation or after a judgment or DOJ settlement of litigation. Inform CIO of any litigation in bankruptcy court or district court, including prior litigation implicating DOJ’s authority to determine dischargeability or the survival of liens against pre-bankruptcy assets (IRC 7122, Compromises, and IRM 25.3.6.1.2(3), Settlement Authority).
Throughout the IRM change update terms, links, and references. Removed the “§” symbol from legal references. Removed italics from IRM titles.

IRM 25.3.6-1 Revised exhibit to remove federal tax lien foreclosure from TC 520 chart under closing code (cc) 70 and adding to cc 80 a federal tax lien foreclosure with or without being combined with a suit to reduce claims to judgment.
Exhibit 25.3.6-3: Added Exhibit titled, TC 971 AC 637 Example.
This supersedes IRM 25.3.5, Open Litigation Control, Monitoring and Closing Actions, dated September 2013.

) The Internal Revenue Service in certain circumstances initiates litigation against a taxpayer or third party when administrative collection enforcement actions alone cannot resolve the case. A taxpayer or third party may also initiate actions where the IRS is or needs to be a party. (
) Purpose: This section provides the procedural instructions for Collection Advisory staff working open litigation controls, including monitoring and closing actions. (

) Audience: This IRM is used by Collection employees controlling open litigation cases. Primarily Collection Advisory staff or Field Collection Revenue Officers use this IRM when controlling open litigation and assisting Counsel or the partment of Justice with actions related to the litigation. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy. Collection Policy is an organization under Small Business/Sell-Employed Division (SBSE), Collection. (
) Program Owner: SBSE, Collection Policy, Enforcement is the program owner of this IRM. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders are the Collection Advisory staff, Chief Counsel, and Department of Justice attorneys. (
) Program Goals: The goal of the program aligns with IRS Strategic Goal II Effectively enforce the law to ensure compliance with tax responsibilities and combat fraud and Objective
to: Enforce Domestic and International Compli- ance by Strengthening expertise, adopting innovative Approaches and Streamlining Procedures. (
) The provisions of this section apply in general to all litigation cases controlled by Advisory. Required actions are to be taken by Advisory unless otherwise noted. Advisory (

) The types of cases normally under Advisory’s control and responsibility are follows: a. Collection suits initiated by Collection employees. b. Civil injunctions to restrain pyramiding. c. Refund suits involving the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP). d. Suits against IRS employees. e. Suits to enjoin or restrain IRS actions involving collection matters. f. Other suits against the IRS (section

, wrongful levy, suits for damages, etc.). g. Cases in which Area Counsel or the Department of Justice speciﬁcally requests Advisory assistance. Note: Proofs of claim in probate proceedings are covered separately in IRM See also the caution with (

Also, with an intervention in a mortgage foreclosure without naming the United States but where its lien may be affected (e.g., if the lien was ﬁled after the mortgage foreclosure action began). Depending upon the nature of the action, the litigation may be handled by either a civil trial attorney in the Tax Division or an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the local U.S. Attorney’s Office. Any actions taken in litigation cases must be coordinated through the Area Counsel Attorney assigned to the case unless the case is of the type that may be handled solely by the local U.S. Attorney’s Office.

) Program Effectiveness: Whenever litigation involving collection matters is pending or the institution of affirmative legal action to effect collection is being considered, advisors are the reviewers of revenue officer recommendation packages ensuring clarity and completeness prior to seeking approval for the action. The approving official reviews the package and if the recommendation represents an effective utilization of collection techniques, approves the package for Counsel’s consideration. The lawyers charged with the responsibil- ity make the ultimate decision of whether to proceed but must rely on those facts and reports provided by the revenue officer when making case decisions. Advisory monitors open litigation and responds to requests and queries from Counsel and DOJ.

) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
fundamental rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accord with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR, see https://www. irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights , Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR). (
) Notiﬁcation: Normally Advisory will receive notice in one of three ways: • receipt through

pproval of a recommendation for suit action from a revenue officer through their manager, • receipt of a summons and complaint against the United States, the Internal Revenue Service, the Department of the Treasury, or an indi- vidual IRS employee in the course of their duties, or • receipt through contact by Area Counsel or the U.S. Attorney. , Approved Recommenda- tions. (

) Initial Review and Actions : Summons and Complaint or Subpoena: Many litigation-related actions have strict time requirements. It is essential that such actions are identiﬁed promptly and taken in a timely fashion. Take the following actions immediately upon receipt of a summons and complaint or other notiﬁ- cation of litigation: Initial Review Actions
receipt through

pproval of a recommendation for suit action from a revenue officer through their manager, receipt of a summons and complaint against the United States, the Internal Revenue Service, the Department of the Treasury, or an indi- vidual IRS employee in the course of their duties, or receipt through contact by Area Counsel or the U.S. Attorney.

Step Immediate Action 1 Determine type - (i.e., what court, action, etc.) 2 Determine response deadlines - (i.e., for response or court hearings) 3 Determine urgency - (i.e., statute of limitations, etc.) and proper course of action 4 Notify Area Counsel: • whenever a complaint ﬁled in a state court proceeding is received, and • whether or not the case should be removed to federal district court. Reminder: The time period for removing an action to federal district court is short, generally within 30 days after receipt of a copy of the complaint. 5 Forward Documents - depending upon the nature of the action and local practice, to: • Area Counsel, and/or • U.S. Attorney’s Office. Reminder: If the response or appearance date is imminent, call Area Counsel and/or the U.S. Attorney’s office to advise, and hand deliver the papers to them if possible 6 Case Files - Establish and maintain case ﬁles for all litigation cases.

Providing testimony (commonly provided by Advisors), and i. Miscellaneous requests. (

) When a current balance due computation is requested: a. Determine the date through which the balance is to be computed. b. Determine the form in which the information is needed. For example, many cases, a simple INTST computation is sufficient. In some, such when settlement is being considered, a breakdown of the remaining liability into tax, penalty, and interest may be needed. INTSTB may be used for this purpose in situations where there is just one assessment tax within a tax module. c. Take any current credit balances into account when computing remaining balances due, and transfer any credit balances to unpaid account modules. Failure to do so may result in unaddressed credit balances being refunded to the taxpayer. Note: Consult with Counsel prior to taking any actions with respect to credit balances. (
